awd_abstract_narration:
The Fall 2018 meeting of the Texas Geometry and Topology Conference will be at Rice University on November 9-11, 2018. To date the Texas Geometry and Topology Conference has been held spring and fall since its founding in 1989, a total of 58 times. The conference has become an extremely successful semiannual event in the Southwest. The next series of conferences will have seven primary host universities: Rice University, Texas A&M University, The University of Texas at Austin, University of Houston, Texas Tech University, and (jointly) Texas Christian University and The University of Texas at Arlington.

By design, the Texas Geometry and Topology Conference has two high-impact foci. First, the conference makes it possible for the community of geometers and topologists from Texas and surrounding states (a huge geographic region) to meet and share mathematics on a regular basis. In so doing, the conference is committed to bring researchers of national and international stature to discuss their research as well as offering a venue for regional scholars and early career researchers. This stimulates individual research and generates productive cooperative efforts between schools. Second, the conference is committed to the strengthening and enrichment of the mathematics personnel base. In order that there be no barrier to participation, the conference is widely advertised, participation is open, and there are no registration fees. Graduate students, junior faculty, women, minorities, and persons with disabilities are especially encouraged to participate and to apply for support. Furthermore the conference is partnering with two historically black universities (Fayetteville State University and Prairie View A&M University) on a project to foster research opportunities for select junior faculty at these institutions.



The permanent web page for the Texas Geometry and Topology Conference: http://www.math.tamu.edu/~tgtc/archive/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Founded in spring 1989, the Texas Geometry and Topology Conference (TGTC) is dedicated to enhancing both the educational and research atmosphere of the community of geometers and topologists in Texas and surrounding states. The TGTC is committed to bringing national and international researchers to the region to discuss their research and interact with mathematicians from Texas and surrounding states. The TGTC provides the community of geometers and topologists from Texas and surrounding states a convenient forum to meet and share mathematics regularly. Graduate students, junior faculty, women, minorities, and persons with disabilities are especially encouraged to participate. 
Over the six years (fall 2018 - spring 2024, extended twice due to the pandemic) for which the current grant cycle has been in effect,  seven conferences have been supported. Highly advertised national-level conferences were held at Rice University ( twice, in fall 2018 and fall 2023) , Texas A&M University (fall 2019), and the University of Texas at Dallas (spring 2022) in which mathematiciansfrom around the country participated. Regional conferences were held twice at Texas ChristianUniversity (spring 2019 and spring 2023), one time at Texas Tech University (spring 2024) togetherwith the online conference at Texas Tech University (spring 2020, no funds were used for this one).In all conferences supported by this grant, there were a total of around 600 registered participants, around 20% of which were female, and 10% were Hispanic/under-represented minorities. The majority (about 3/4)  of participants were juniorfaculty, post-doctoral students, graduate students, and undergraduate students. Graduate student participants constituted about 3/4 of this population.  60 speakers,(of whom 15 were female) from top national and international (including several world-renowned mathematicians) delivered 66 lectures that covered all contemporarily active research areas of geometry and topology. 
Each conference started with an expositorylecture aimed exclusively at graduate students. The broad scope of the lectures illuminated the most important research directions, as an impulse and guidance for participants, especially junior ones, in their future research. The lectures and discussions during the conferences stimulate interaction and collaboration between disparate research communities in Geometry and Topology nationwide.Most of the talks were exemplary from the pedagogical point of view and had an obvious impact on graduate students and junior faculty on how to prepare their research presentations, which is an important part of professional development.
The TGTC continued to collaborate with two historically black universities, Fayetteville State University and Prairie View A&M University, whereby young faculty from these institutions attended most of the conferences and reported. These faculty have reported favorably about research contacts made, pertinent talks, and present and future ideas and publications.
